message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Communication and Control in Collaborative UAVs: Recent Advances and Future Trends
Paper Abstract: The recent progress in unmanned aerial vehicles (UAV) technology has significantly advanced UAV-based applications for military, civil, and commercial domains. Nevertheless, the challenges of establishing high-speed communication links, flexible control strategies, and developing efficient collaborative decision-making algorithms for a swarm of UAVs limit their autonomy, robustness, and reliability. Thus, a growing focus has been witnessed on collaborative communication to allow a swarm of UAVs to coordinate and communicate autonomously for the cooperative completion of tasks in a short time with improved efficiency and reliability. This work presents a comprehensive review of collaborative communication in a multi-UAV system. We thoroughly discuss the characteristics of intelligent UAVs and their communication and control requirements for autonomous collaboration and coordination. Moreover, we review various UAV collaboration tasks, summarize the applications of UAV swarm networks for dense urban environments and present the use case scenarios to highlight the current developments of UAV-based applications in various domains. Finally, we identify several exciting future research direction that needs attention for advancing the research in collaborative UAVs.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

I've completed the web search for "Unmanned aerial vehicle." Here's a summary of what I found:

## Overview

An unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) or unmanned aircraft system (UAS), commonly known as a drone, is an aircraft with no human pilot, crew, or passengers on board, but rather is controlled remotely or is autonomous.

## Key Characteristics

A UAV is capable of controlled, sustained level flight and is powered by a jet, reciprocating, or electric engine.(no content)A UAV differs from a cruise missile in that a UAV is intended to be recovered after its mission, while a cruise missile impacts its target.

## History

The earliest recorded use of an unmanned aerial vehicle for warfighting occurred in July 1849, with Austrian forces besieging Venice attempting to launch incendiary balloons at the besieged city.(no content)The Spanish engineer Leonardo Torres Quevedo introduced a radio-based control-system called the Telekino at the Paris Academy of Science in 1903, as a way of testing airships without risking human life.

## Modern Applications

Unmanned aerial vehicles are used across the world for civilian, commercial, as well as military applications, with over 237 identified ways that drones revolutionize business across 15 industries including agriculture, energy, construction, and mining.

The search results show that UAVs have diverse applications ranging from reconnaissance and surveillance to agriculture, disaster response, and commercial photography.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Distributed decision-making"

Links: [{"title":"Decentralized decision-making - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decentralized_decision-making"},{"title":"Egalitarian community - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Egalitarian_communities"},{"title":"Decision theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uncertainty_modeling"},{"title":"Next-best-action marketing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Next-best-action_marketing"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about distributed decision-making:

## Definition and Core Concept

Distributed decision-making is any process where the decision-making authority is distributed throughout a larger group.(no content)It also connotes a higher authority given to lower level functionaries, executives, and workers.

## Applications and Context

This can be in any organization of any size; it may be present in a governmental authority to a corporation. Additionally, in the emerging field of socio-cognitive engineering, the research is especially focused on the different types of distributed decision-making in human organizations, in normal and abnormal/emergency/crisis situations.

## Benefits and Implications

Distributed decision-making tends to create less rigidity and flatter hierarchies in organizations. When upper management delegates decision-making responsibilities, there also exist wider spans of control among managers, creating a more lateral flow of information. Thus, there will be more bottom up directional information flow, allowing for more innovation and efficiency closer to the means of production.

## Military and Real-Time Applications

In a military context it describes thinking on the fly with distributed, local decision-making versus planned campaigns and objectives.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Web search results for query: "Cooperative control"

Links: [{"title":"Cooperative multitasking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cooperative_multitasking"},{"title":"Cooperative - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cooperative"},{"title":"Collaborative Control Theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collaborative_Control_Theory"},{"title":"Worker cooperative - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Worker_cooperative"},{"title":"Communication, navigation and surveillance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Communication,_navigation_and_surveillance"},{"title":"Cooperative Adaptive Cruise Control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cooperative_Adaptive_Cruise_Control"},{"title":"Consumer cooperative - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consumer_cooperative"},{"title":"Workers' control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Workers'_control"},{"title":"Rochdale Principles - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cooperative_principles"},{"title":"Consumers' co-operative - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consumers'_co-operative"}]

Based on the search results, "cooperative control" can refer to several different concepts depending on the context:

## Technology and Systems

In systems design, collaboration is an essential means for effective design and control of e-Work, enabling all the entities involved in a decentralized system to share their resources, information, and responsibilities, such that mutual benefits are obtained and sustained.

In transportation, Cooperative Adaptive Cruise Control (CACC) is an extension to the adaptive cruise control (ACC) concept using Vehicle-to-Everything (V2X) communication.

## Business and Organizations

A cooperative is "an autonomous association of persons united voluntarily to meet their common economic, social and cultural needs and aspirations through a jointly owned and democratically-controlled enterprise".

For worker-managed organizations specifically, worker-owners work in the business, govern it and manage it, and ownership and decision-making power of a worker cooperative should be vested solely with the worker-owners and ultimate authority rests with the worker-owners as a whole.

## Operating Systems

In computing, cooperative multitasking is a computer multitasking technique in which the operating system never initiates a context switch from a running process to another process.

The specific meaning depends on whether you're referring to technical systems, business organization, or computing contexts. Would you like more detailed information about any particular type of cooperative control?

Links: [{"title":"Cooperative multitasking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cooperative_multitasking"},{"title":"Cooperative - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cooperative"},{"title":"Collaborative Control Theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collaborative_Control_Theory"},{"title":"Worker cooperative - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Worker_cooperative"},{"title":"Communication, navigation and surveillance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Communication,_navigation_and_surveillance"},{"title":"Cooperative Adaptive Cruise Control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cooperative_Adaptive_Cruise_Control"},{"title":"Consumer cooperative - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consumer_cooperative"},{"title":"Workers' control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Workers'_control"},{"title":"Rochdale Principles - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cooperative_principles"},{"title":"Consumers' co-operative - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consumers'_co-operative"}]

Based on the search results, "cooperative control" can refer to several different concepts depending on the context:

## Technology and Systems

In systems design, collaboration is an essential means for effective design and control of e-Work, enabling all the entities involved in a decentralized system to share their resources, information, and responsibilities, such that mutual benefits are obtained and sustained.

In transportation, Cooperative Adaptive Cruise Control (CACC) is an extension to the adaptive cruise control (ACC) concept using Vehicle-to-Everything (V2X) communication.

## Business and Organizations

A cooperative is "an autonomous association of persons united voluntarily to meet their common economic, social and cultural needs and aspirations through a jointly owned and democratically-controlled enterprise".

For worker-managed organizations specifically, worker-owners work in the business, govern it and manage it, and ownership and decision-making power of a worker cooperative should be vested solely with the worker-owners and ultimate authority rests with the worker-owners as a whole.

## Operating Systems

In computing, cooperative multitasking is a computer multitasking technique in which the operating system never initiates a context switch from a running process to another process.

The specific meaning depends on whether you're referring to technical systems, business organization, or computing contexts. Would you like more detailed information about any particular type of cooperative control?

Web search results for query: "Communication systems"

Links: [{"title":"Communications system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Communications_system"},{"title":"Category:Wireless communication systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Wireless_communication_systems"},{"title":"Emergency communication system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emergency_communication_system"},{"title":"Group communication system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Group_communication_system"},{"title":"Communications and information systems of the British Armed Forces - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Communications_and_information_systems_of_the_British_Armed_Forces"},{"title":"Coherence time (communications systems) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coherence_time_(communications_systems)"},{"title":"Brocade Communications Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brocade_Communications_Systems"},{"title":"Communication protocol - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Communication_protocol"},{"title":"Telecommunications - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Telecommunications"},{"title":"NATO Communications and Information Systems Services Agency - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NATO_Communications_and_Information_Systems_Services_Agency"}]

Based on the web search results, here's an overview of communication systems:

## Overview

Communication systems allow the transfer of information from one place to another or from one device to another through a specified channel or medium.

## Types of Communication Systems

There are several different types of communication systems:

**Optical Communication Systems**: An optical communication system is any form of communications system that uses light as the transmission medium, with equipment consisting of a transmitter, which encodes a message into an optical signal, a communication channel, which carries the signal to its destination, and a receiver, which reproduces the message from the received optical signal.

**Wireless Communication Systems**: Wireless communication systems are systems that use wireless 'over the air' technologies to create a telecommunications channel between two points.

**Duplex Systems**: A duplex communication system is a system composed of two connected parties or devices which can communicate with one another in both directions, and duplex systems are employed in nearly all communications networks.

**Emergency Communication Systems**: An emergency communication system is any system (typically computer-based) that is organized for the primary purpose of supporting one-way and two-way communication of emergency information between both individuals and groups of individuals, and these systems are commonly designed to convey information over multiple types of devices, from signal lights to text messaging to live, streaming video.

## Communication Protocols

A communication protocol is a system of rules that allows two or more entities of a communications system to transmit information, and the protocol defines the rules, syntax, semantics, and synchronization of communication and possible error recovery methods.

Links: [{"title":"Swarm robotic platforms - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_robotic_platforms"},{"title":"Swarm robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_robotics"},{"title":"Ant robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ant_robotics"},{"title":"Swarm (novelette) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_(novelette)"},{"title":"Swarm intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_intelligence"},{"title":"Kilobot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kilobot"},{"title":"S-bot mobile robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/S-bot_mobile_robot"},{"title":"Sabine Hauert - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sabine_Hauert"},{"title":"Gerardo Beni - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gerardo_Beni"},{"title":"IISc Guidance, Control and Decision Systems Laboratory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mobile_Robotics_Laboratory_at_IISc"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of swarm robotics:

## Definition and Concept

Swarm robotic platforms apply swarm robotics in multi-robot collaboration.(no content)They take inspiration from nature, such as collective problem solving mechanisms seen in nature like honey bee aggregation.

## Key Characteristics

Unlike distributed robotic systems in general, swarm robotics emphasizes a large number of robots. The robots in a swarm follow several important principles:

- Robots are autonomous, do not exploit centralized swarm control or global knowledge, and cooperate with each other to accomplish the given task.
- Robots possess local perceiving and communicating capabilities, such as wireless transmission systems, like radio frequency or infrared.
- Miniaturization is also key factor in swarm robotics, as the effect of thousands of small robots can maximize the effect of the swarm-intelligent approach to achieve meaningful behavior.

## History

The phrase "swarm robotics" was reported to make its first appearance in 1991 according to Google Scholar, but research regarding swarm robotics began to grow in early 2000s.(no content)One of the first international projects regarding swarm robotics was the SWARM-BOTS project funded by the European Commission between 2001 and 2005.

## Applications

A promising use of swarm robotics is in search and rescue missions, where swarms of robots of different sizes could be sent to places that rescue-workers cannot reach safely, to explore the unknown environment and solve complex mazes via onboard sensors.(no content)Progress has been made in the application of autonomous swarms in the field of manufacturing, known as swarm 3D printing, which is particularly useful for the production of large structures and components.

Links: [{"title":"Autonomous system (Internet) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_system_(Internet)"},{"title":"Wallenberg AI, Autonomous Systems and Software Program - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wallenberg_AI,_Autonomous_Systems_and_Software_Program"},{"title":"Autonomous Agents and Multi-Agent Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_Agents_and_Multi-Agent_Systems"},{"title":"Autonomous system (mathematics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_system_(mathematics)"},{"title":"Autonomous system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_system"},{"title":"List of driverless train systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_driverless_train_systems"},{"title":"Annual Review of Control, Robotics, and Autonomous Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Annual_Review_of_Control,_Robotics,_and_Autonomous_Systems"},{"title":"Autonomous decentralized system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_decentralized_system"},{"title":"Autonomous agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_agent"},{"title":"Autonomous robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_robot"}]

I've completed the web search for "Autonomous systems." Here are the results showing various meanings and applications:

## Key Findings:

**Multiple Definitions:**
The search results reveal that "autonomous systems" has several contexts:

1. **Internet Autonomous Systems**: An autonomous system (AS) is a collection of connected Internet Protocol (IP) routing prefixes under the control of one or more network operatorson behalf of a single administrative entity or domain, that presents a common and clearly defined routing policy to the Internet.

2. **Autonomous Agents**: An autonomous agent is an artificial intelligence (AI) system that can perform complex tasks independently.(no content)An autonomous agent is a system situated within and a part of an environment that senses that environment and acts on it, over time, in pursuit of its own agenda and so as to effect what it senses in the future.

3. **Autonomous Decentralized Systems**: An autonomous decentralized system (or ADS) is a decentralized system composed of modules or components that are designed to operate independently but are capable of interacting with each other to meet the overall goal of the system.

4. **Autonomous Robots**: These include systems ranging from domestic robots to advanced navigation systems. The most advanced systems now fuse information from various sensors for both localization (position) and navigation.

5. **Mathematical Systems**: In mathematics, an autonomous system or autonomous differential equation is a system of ordinary differential equations which does not explicitly depend on the independent variable.

The search results also show that research in autonomous systems is active and growing, with programs like Sweden's WASP program and dedicated journals covering developments in this field.

Links: [{"title":"Autonomous system (Internet) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_system_(Internet)"},{"title":"Wallenberg AI, Autonomous Systems and Software Program - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wallenberg_AI,_Autonomous_Systems_and_Software_Program"},{"title":"Autonomous Agents and Multi-Agent Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_Agents_and_Multi-Agent_Systems"},{"title":"Autonomous system (mathematics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_system_(mathematics)"},{"title":"Autonomous system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_system"},{"title":"List of driverless train systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_driverless_train_systems"},{"title":"Annual Review of Control, Robotics, and Autonomous Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Annual_Review_of_Control,_Robotics,_and_Autonomous_Systems"},{"title":"Autonomous decentralized system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_decentralized_system"},{"title":"Autonomous agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_agent"},{"title":"Autonomous robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_robot"}]

I've completed the web search for "Autonomous systems." Here are the results showing various meanings and applications:

## Key Findings:

**Multiple Definitions:**
The search results reveal that "autonomous systems" has several contexts:

1. **Internet Autonomous Systems**: An autonomous system (AS) is a collection of connected Internet Protocol (IP) routing prefixes under the control of one or more network operatorson behalf of a single administrative entity or domain, that presents a common and clearly defined routing policy to the Internet.

2. **Autonomous Agents**: An autonomous agent is an artificial intelligence (AI) system that can perform complex tasks independently.(no content)An autonomous agent is a system situated within and a part of an environment that senses that environment and acts on it, over time, in pursuit of its own agenda and so as to effect what it senses in the future.

3. **Autonomous Decentralized Systems**: An autonomous decentralized system (or ADS) is a decentralized system composed of modules or components that are designed to operate independently but are capable of interacting with each other to meet the overall goal of the system.

4. **Autonomous Robots**: These include systems ranging from domestic robots to advanced navigation systems. The most advanced systems now fuse information from various sensors for both localization (position) and navigation.

5. **Mathematical Systems**: In mathematics, an autonomous system or autonomous differential equation is a system of ordinary differential equations which does not explicitly depend on the independent variable.

The search results also show that research in autonomous systems is active and growing, with programs like Sweden's WASP program and dedicated journals covering developments in this field.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Control systems"

Links: [{"title":"Control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_system"},{"title":"Systems control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Systems_control"},{"title":"Systems and Control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Systems_and_Control"},{"title":"Industrial control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Industrial_control_system"},{"title":"Annual Review of Control, Robotics, and Autonomous Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Annual_Review_of_Control,_Robotics,_and_Autonomous_Systems"},{"title":"Category:Air pollution control systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Air_pollution_control_systems"},{"title":"Industrial process control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Industrial_process_control"},{"title":"Linear control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_control"},{"title":"Smoke control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Smoke_control"},{"title":"Adaptive collaborative control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_collaborative_control"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about control systems:

## What is a Control System?

A control system manages, commands, directs, or regulates the behavior of other devices or systems using control loops.(no content)It can range from a single home heating controller using a thermostat controlling a domestic boiler to large industrial control systems which are used for controlling processes.

## Types of Control Systems

**Feedback Control Systems:** A closed-loop controller or feedback controller is a control loop which incorporates feedback, in contrast to an open-loop controller or non-feedback controller. A closed-loop controller uses feedback to control states or outputs of a dynamical system.

**Open-Loop Systems:** Open-loop control systems do not make use of feedback, and run only in pre-arranged ways.

## Applications and Examples

An everyday example is the cruise control on a road vehicle; where external influences such as hills would cause speed changes, and the driver has the ability to alter the desired set speed.(no content)Logic controllers may respond to switches and sensors and can cause the machinery to start and stop various operations through the use of actuators. Logic controllers are used to sequence mechanical operations in many applications. Examples include elevators, washing machines and other systems with interrelated operations.

## Industrial Control Systems

An industrial control system (ICS) is an electronic control system and associated instrumentation used for industrial process control.(no content)Larger systems are usually implemented by supervisory control and data acquisition (SCADA) systems, or DCSs, and programmable logic controllers (PLCs).(no content)Industrial process control (IPC) or simply process control is a system used in modern manufacturing which uses the principles of control theory and physical industrial control systems to monitor, control and optimize continuous industrial production processes using control algorithms. This ensures that the industrial machines run smoothly and safely in factories and efficiently use energy to transform raw materials into high-quality finished products.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Based on the search results, I can provide you with comprehensive information about Adaptive Collaborative Control:

## Overview

Adaptive collaborative control is a decision-making approach that enables humans and robots to work together as partners rather than in traditional master-slave relationships.(no content)It allows autonomous agents (robots) and human operators to collaborate as peers, sharing decision-making responsibilities to accomplish common goals.

## Key Characteristics

Robots operating under collaborative control must possess three essential characteristics: they must be self-reliant (capable of independent operation), aware (able to perceive and understand their environment and situation), and adaptive (able to modify their behavior based on changing conditions).

## Implementation Approach

This methodology is implemented through hybrid computational models that combine finite-state machines with functional models as subcomponents, which simulate the behavior of multi-agent systems where both human and robotic participants contribute to task execution and work product development.

## Decision-Making Structure

The constraints operate primarily at the strategic level, governing high-level goals and tasks as defined by human operators, while lower-level tactical decisions remain adaptive and flexible, accommodating varying degrees of autonomy, interaction patterns, and capabilities of different agents.

## Historical Development

The concept of "collaborative control" was first developed in the late 1990s and early 2000s by Fong, Thorpe, and Baur.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Robots operating under collaborative control must possess three essential characteristics: they must be self-reliant (capable of independent operation), aware (able to perceive and understand their environment and situation), and adaptive (able to modify their behavior based on changing conditions).

## Implementation Approach

This methodology is implemented through hybrid computational models that combine finite-state machines with functional models as subcomponents, which simulate the behavior of multi-agent systems where both human and robotic participants contribute to task execution and work product development.

## Decision-Making Structure

The constraints operate primarily at the strategic level, governing high-level goals and tasks as defined by human operators, while lower-level tactical decisions remain adaptive and flexible, accommodating varying degrees of autonomy, interaction patterns, and capabilities of different agents.

## Historical Development

The concept of "collaborative control" was first developed in the late 1990s and early 2000s by Fong, Thorpe, and Baur.
